text: I was actually sitting next to your
gentleman on the bus and this is where
he lived these are family homes and this
is why they've had to flee no we've had
a number of briefings from the fire
chief here he calls this fiery Beast he
said it jumped across roads he said
everything they did just didn't seem to
work they have dropped water from above
they have had horses trying to save
these family homes but it just simply
wasn't enough to save this area we came
from another area a little earlier again
I was told that it was one of the nicest
areas to live in in Fort McMurray and
these are areas where a number of oil
workers come to stay and certainly I've
met a number of people who are from here
and when they see these pictures of
their homes I know this is going to be
utterly devastating for them one of the
things that's very interesting as you're
driving along is although you see these
huge areas of devastation the other
thing you do see is part of the
infrastructure are still impact so the
hospital is still standing there are a
number of hotels still standing but the
water has been contaminated there are
areas around here that it's just simply
not safe we are allowed to get off and
carts or fort mcmurray and then we have
to get back on the bus because they know
that this is still an evacuation zone
now when it comes to the fire itself the
wind is still blowing quite strongly
which is not helping when it comes to
fighting these flames for what is
helping is the cooler temperatures that
dropped about 10 degrees in the last two
days and we're told that this is good
weather to fight fires but I think today
and I think one of the things that
people will take away from this trip are
these images these are the first images
that we've seen the first time that the
media has been allowed n and this will
be a difficult thing for residents to
watch
